summary.para: Lists values that specify how to aggregate series points.

For most series types, the Average function is automatically applied. For Range Area and Range Bar series types, the Range function is used. For Stock and Candlestick series types, the Financial function is used.
Calculates the average value for a selected numeric or date-time interval.
Calculates the number of non-null values for a selected numeric or date-time interval.

Use this function for Stock and Candlestick series types. The function aggregates financial data for a selected interval into a single high-low-open-close data point: * the high value equals the highest value of all data points in this interval; * the low value equals the lowest value of all data points; * the open value equals the open value of the first data point; * the close value equals the close value of the last data point.
Calculates the maximum value for a selected numeric or date-time interval.
Calculates the minimum value for a selected numeric or date-time interval.
Use this function for Range Area and Range Bar series types. The function calculates the range of values for a selected numeric or date-time interval.
Calculates the summary for a selected numeric or date-time interval.
Lists values that specify next to which edge the Chart should display an axis.
The Chart displays an axis next to the right or top edge of the pane.
The Chart displays an axis next to the left or bottom edge of the pane.
Lists values that specify whether and how to cast the chart’s arguments and values.
Does not cast arguments/values and displays them on the axis of the applicable type (Continuous for integer and float data types and Discrete for other data types).
Casts arguments/values to the DateTime type and displays them on the Continuous axis. To parse strings successfully, the value should match the ISO JavaScript Date pattern.
Casts arguments/values to a numeric type and displays them on the Continuous axis. To parse strings successfully, the decimal separator should be ‘.’.
Casts arguments/values to the String type and displays them on the Discrete axis.
Lists formats applied to axis and series labels.
Displays numbers as a billion (1 000 000 000.11 → 1B).
Adds a currency symbol to a number (3.95 → $3.95).
Displays a current day (for example, 01).
Displays a day of the week (for example, Thursday).
Displays a decimal number (100.11 → 100).
Label values are not formatted.
Displays a number in exponential notation (1 000 → 1E+3).
Displays a number with a fixed point.
Displays hours (for example, 12).
Uses “Thousands”, “Millions”, “Billions”, or “Trillions” format depending on the actual value.
Displays a date in the dddd, MMMM dd, yyyy format (for example, Thursday, January 01, 1970).
Displays a date-time value in the dddd, MMMM dd, yyyy, hh:mm:ss format (for example, Thursday, January 01, 1970, 12:00:00 AM).
Displays a time value in the hh:mm:ss format (for example, 12:00:00 AM).
Displays numbers as a million (1 000 000.11 → 1M).
Displays milliseconds (for example, 010).
Displays time in minutes (for example, 00).
Displays months (for example, January).
Displays a date in the MMMM dd format (for example, January 01).
Displays a date in the yyyy MMMM format (for example, 1970 January)
Displays numbers as percentile values (for example, 0.1 → 10%).
Displays a quarter of the year for a date (for example, QI).
Displays a quarter and year (for example, QI 1970).
Displays seconds (for example, 00).
Displays a date in the m/dd/yyyy format (for example, 1/25/1970 AM).
Displays a date in the m/dd/yyyy, hh:mm format (for example, 1/25/1970, 12:00 AM).
Displays time in the hh:mm format (for example, “12:00 AM”).
Displays numbers as a thousand (1 000.11 → 1K).
Displays numbers as a trillion (1 000 000 000 000 → 1T).
Displays years (for example, 1970).
Contains options to specify tick intervals.
Returns an interval of one day.

summary.para: Lists values that specify how to group data rows.
Rows are grouped by the character that the column values start with.
Custom logic is used to group grid data.
For date/time columns, rows are grouped by the date part of their values. The time part is ignored.
For date/time columns, rows are grouped by the month part of their values.

For date/time columns, rows are combined into the following non-overlapping groups according to their date value as compared with today’s date: “Beyond Next Month”, “Next Month”, “Later this Month”, “Three Weeks Away”, “Two Weeks Away”, “Next Week”, “Today”, “Tomorrow”, “Yesterday”, “Sunday”, “Monday”, “Tuesday”, “Wednesday”, “Thursday”, “Friday”, “Saturday”, “Last Week”, “Two Weeks Ago”, “Three Weeks Ago”, “Earlier this Month”, “Last Month”, “Older”.
For date/time columns, rows are grouped by the year part of their values.
For date/time columns, this option is the same as the Date option. For non date/time columns, this option is the same as the Value option.
Rows are grouped by the column values’ display text.
Rows are grouped by the column values.

member.param: A string value that specifies a key.

summary.para: Lists automatic value completion modes.
The autocomplete feature is disabled. A user should type each character into the edit box.

When a user enters a character in the empty edit box for the first time, the editor fills all the placeholders with the default values. 0 is the default character for placeholders that accept numeric values. For placeholders that accept letters, a is the default character.

Each time a user types a character, the editor determines if the following placeholder can be filled. If only one character matches the mask, the editor displays this character and moves the caret forward.
Lists caret navigation modes for Date-Time masks.
After users enter and completes a specific part of a date/time value, the caret moves to the following part of a date/time value that can be edited.
After users enter a specific part of a date/time value, they should use the keyboard or mouse to move the caret to another part.
Lists mask modes.
The component activates a mask type based on the data type.
The component activates the Date-time mask type.
The component activates the Numeric mask type.
The component activates the Regular Expression mask type.
The component activates the Text mask type.
Lists values that define how users can resize the Memo component.
Users are not allowed to resize the component.
Users can only change the component’s width.
Users can only change the component height.
Users can change both the component height and width.
Lists values that specify whether the menu hides root items’ text and displays icons instead when the width of the browser window changes.
The text for all menu items with associated icons is hidden.
Menu item text is not hidden or replaced with an icon. If the width of the window changes, items are positioned across multiple rows or collapsed to a hamburger menu (if is true).
Menu items are hidden sequentially from the last menu item. You can also use the property to specify the order in which menu items are hidden.
Lists value that specify how the menu is displayed on different devices.
Mobile and tablet devices show the menu in a compact view. Other device types show the menu as a panel with root items.
The menu is shown as a panel with root items. Child items are available in drop-down menus.
The menu in a compact view.
Lists values that specify which action opens a menu item’s submenu.
The submenu opens when the menu item is clicked.
In mobile mode, the submenu opens when the menu item is hovered over. In desktop mode, the submenu opens when the menu item is clicked. Refer to .
The submenu opens when the menu item is hovered over.
Lists values that specify the hamburger button’s position.
Mobile and tablet devices display this button at the right edge of the menu panel. Other device types display the button at the left edge of the menu panel. Depends on the property value.
The button is placed at the left edge of the menu panel.
Mobile and tablet devices display this button at the left edge of the menu panel. Other devices display the button at the right edge of the menu panel. Depends on the property value.
The button is placed closer to the right edge of the menu panel.

member.name: P:DevExpress.Blazor.TabClickEventArgs.MouseEventArgs

summary.para: The Blazor’s built-in event arguments.

member.value: A object that stores mouse-related data for the event.

summary.para: Gets the clicked tab’s index.
Lists values that specify how the component loads tabs content.
The component renders the content of all tabs in the DOM and maintains the tab’s state. This mode speeds up navigation between tabs, but can increase memory consumption.

The component initially loads only content of an active tab. When a user selects another tab, its content replaces the content of the previously active tab in the DOM. Note the component does not keep the tab’s state.

The component initially loads content of an active tab, then loads the content of other tabs when a user selects them. In this case, the component maintains the tab’s state. Use this mode to improve performance of your application.
Lists values that specify how users navigate between tabs when they do not fit the container’s width.
This scroll mode automatically adapts to the device type. Mobile and tablet devices use Swipe mode. Desktop devices use NavButtons mode.

The container displays tabs that fit the width. Users can navigate to other tabs in the following ways: use the navigation buttons; hover the cursor over a tab with the Shift key pressed and scroll the mouse wheel; or swipe (mobile devices only).
Users cannot scroll tabs. The tabs that do not fit the container’s width are moved to a new line.
The container displays a few tabs that fit the width. To navigate to other tabs, users can swipe tabs, or hover the mouse pointer over the container, hold the Shift key, and scroll the mouse wheel.
Lists values that define how a TagBox located within the standard EditForm is validated.

If the property is specified, the editor’s tags are validated. If the property is specified, the editor’s values are validated. If both Tags and Values properties are specified, the editor’s values are validated.
The editor’s tags are validated.
The editor’s values are validated.
